answers.author: Pooja Varma
answers.text:
Hi Erin,
I was not able to locate Florida specific policies regarding information centers in government buildings however I did find a few ICMA documents that may be useful to you. 
The Public Use of City Hall policy from Bangor, Maine locates information booths or displays in the lobby where other public events are held. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/6731/Public_Use_of_City_Hall 
The Ponca City, Oklahoma standard operation policy on the knowledge Network includes “informational handouts” where pamphlets and brochures must relate to City business. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/12950/SOP_City_Hall_Building 
A document describing Bedford, Virginia’s city and county Welcome Center that provides tourist information as well as serves as a community center where meetings and function may be held. 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/6740/Welcome_Center_Serves_Visitors_and_Locals
I hope this is helpful,
Pooja Varma 
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
pvarma@icma.org

Pooja Varma

answers.author: Cory Fleming
answers.text:
The City of Jacksonville, FL, maintains two locations for walk-in customers. Monica Cichowlas, the City's Customer Service Manager, can answer questions about how they manage their centers.  Her e-mail address is MonicaC@coj.net.

author: Erin Bryce
text:
I am curious to know if there are any Florida cities who provide information centers inside their government buildings where people can pick up brochures, flyers, pamphlets, etc. from the community. I am looking to create one inside City Hall in North Port, and wanted to know if there are Florida agencies who have policies in place on how to handle such a spot inside a government building.
Please let me know.
Sincerely,
Erin Bryce, Community Outreach Manager
City of North Port, Florida
ebryce@cityofnorthport.com
title: Information Center
